definitions: coat or cover a surface with copper metal or copper-colored material
examples: The artisan coppered the decorative bowl before polishing
They decided to copper the roof for better durability

definitions: engage in sexual intercourse with another individual, especially referring to animals
examples: The animals copulate during their mating season every spring
Scientists observed the insects copulating under laboratory conditions

definitions: make an identical or similar version of something original
imitate or reproduce someone's behavior, style, or actions deliberately
examples: Please copy these documents before the meeting starts tomorrow
The printer can copy fifty pages per minute efficiently
Children often copy their parents' behavior without realizing it
The artist was accused of copying another painter's technique

definitions: secure legal protection for original creative work against unauthorized reproduction or use
examples: The author copyrighted her novel before sending it to publishers
You should copyright your software code to protect your work

definitions: fasten or bind something using a cord, rope, or similar flexible material
examples: They corded the packages together for easier transport today
The workers corded the logs before loading them onto trucks

definitions: remove the central part or seeds from fruit or vegetables
examples: She cored the apples before making the pie filling
The chef cored twenty pears for the dessert preparation

definitions: close or seal a bottle or container using a cork stopper
examples: The winemaker corked hundreds of bottles after fermentation completed
They carefully corked the vintage wine for long-term storage

definitions: move or cause to move in a twisting spiral pattern or motion
examples: The plane corkscrewed through the clouds during the airshow
The smoke corkscrewed upward from the chimney into darkness

definitions: preserve meat, especially beef, by curing it in salt water or brine
examples: They corned the beef using traditional Irish methods yesterday
The butcher corns his own meat for the delicatessen

definitions: force someone or something into a position where escape is difficult
gain control of the entire supply of a commodity to manipulate prices
examples: The detective cornered the suspect in the abandoned warehouse
The cat cornered the mouse against the kitchen wall
The company attempted to corner the market on rare metals
Investors cornered the silver market causing prices to skyrocket

definitions: gather and confine animals or people into an enclosed or restricted area
examples: The cowboys corralled the cattle before the storm arrived
Teachers corralled the students into the gymnasium for assembly

definitions: identify and fix mistakes or errors in something written or calculated
point out faults in someone's behavior to improve their conduct
examples: The teacher corrected all the exam papers over the weekend
Please correct any spelling errors before submitting the document
Parents must correct their children's behavior when necessary sometimes
The supervisor corrected the employee's unprofessional attitude at work

definitions: establish or demonstrate a mutual relationship or connection between two or more things
examples: Researchers correlate smoking with increased risk of lung cancer
The data correlates temperature changes with migration patterns clearly

definitions: have a close similarity or match with something in nature or character
communicate with someone by exchanging letters or emails over time
examples: These results correspond with our initial hypothesis about growth
The symptoms correspond to those described in medical literature
She corresponded with her pen pal for over ten years
The scientists corresponded regularly about their research findings yesterday

definitions: confirm or give support to a statement, theory, or finding with additional evidence
examples: The witness testimony corroborates the defendant's alibi perfectly well
Scientific experiments corroborate the theoretical predictions made last year

definitions: cause someone to become dishonest or morally compromised through bribes or influence
alter or damage computer data making it unreliable or unusable
examples: Power and money can corrupt even the most principled individuals
The scandal revealed how lobbyists corrupted several government officials
The virus corrupted all the files on the hard drive
A power outage corrupted the database during the backup process

definitions: dress up and act as a fictional character from movies, games, or anime
examples: She cosplays her favorite anime character at conventions annually
Fans cosplay as superheroes for the comic book festival

definitions: require a specified payment or price to purchase or obtain something
cause the loss of something valuable as a consequence of action
examples: The new laptop costs two thousand dollars including warranty
How much does this service cost per month exactly?
His reckless behavior cost him his job and reputation
The mistake cost the company millions in lost revenue

definitions: dress someone or oneself in special clothing for performance or celebration
examples: The theater company costumed all actors in period clothing
Parents costumed their children as pirates for Halloween night

definitions: begin to understand or realize something gradually, especially something previously unclear
examples: She finally cottoned on to what he was suggesting
It took him ages to cotton to their scheme

definitions: express something in language of a particular style or manner deliberately
examples: The lawyer couched her argument in careful legal terminology
He couched his criticism in diplomatic language to avoid offense

definitions: expel air from the lungs suddenly with a harsh sound
reluctantly give or produce something, especially money or information
examples: She coughed persistently throughout the entire concert last night
The patient has been coughing for three weeks now
He finally coughed up the money he owed me
The witness coughed up new information during intense questioning

definitions: give advice, especially on social or personal problems in a professional capacity
examples: The therapist counsels teenagers struggling with anxiety and depression
She counseled him to seek legal representation before proceeding

definitions: determine the total number of items in a collection systematically
be significant or have value in a particular situation or context
depend on someone for help or support in achieving something
examples: The teacher counted all the students before leaving class
Can you count how many boxes we have left?
Every vote counts in this extremely close election race
Your opinion really counts in this important decision
You can always count on her during difficult times
I'm counting on you to finish this project

definitions: accept, approve, or give support to something, especially reluctantly or formally
examples: The board will not countenance any unethical business practices
She refused to countenance such rude behavior from students

definitions: speak or act in opposition to something or respond to an argument
examples: She countered his argument with compelling statistical evidence today
The company countered the allegations with a detailed statement

definitions: act against something to reduce its force or neutralize its effect
examples: This medicine counteracts the poison's effects on the nervous system
Exercise helps counteract the negative effects of prolonged sitting

definitions: make an attack in response to one by an opponent or enemy
examples: The army counterattacked at dawn catching the enemy unprepared
The team counterattacked quickly after losing possession of ball

definitions: offset or neutralize something with an opposing force or influence of equal strength
examples: The benefits counterbalance the risks in this investment strategy
Her experience counterbalances his innovative ideas perfectly in partnership

definitions: illegally imitate something valuable with the intention to deceive or defraud
examples: Criminals counterfeit money using sophisticated printing equipment these days
The gang counterfeited designer handbags and sold them online

definitions: provide a pleasing or notable contrast to something else in art or discussion
examples: The violin melody counterpoints the deep cello bass beautifully
Her practical approach counterpoints his theoretical perspective in debates

definitions: balance something with a weight or force acting in the opposite direction
examples: Engineers counterweighted the elevator for smooth operation throughout building
The crane operator counterweighted the load to prevent tipping

definitions: connect or combine two things together mechanically or conceptually
form a romantic or sexual relationship with another person
examples: The engineer coupled the train cars before departure time
Scientists coupled these theories to explain the phenomenon
They coupled after meeting at the university dance party
The two celebrities coupled despite their age difference

definitions: try to win the affection of someone for romantic purposes
attempt to win or gain something through deliberate effort or attention
examples: He courted her for two years before proposing marriage
In Victorian times, gentlemen courted ladies with flowers
The company courts investors with impressive quarterly profit reports
Politicians court voters with promises of tax reform

definitions: agree to a formal binding agreement, especially one concerning property or religious matters
examples: The parties covenanted to maintain the shared boundary fence
They covenanted with God to follow religious laws faithfully

definitions: put something on top of or in front of something to protect or conceal
include, deal with, or provide for something in scope or content
travel a specified distance or area during movement or exploration
report on an event or subject for news media or publication
examples: Please cover the food to keep flies away today
Snow covered the mountain peaks throughout the winter months
The insurance covers damage from natural disasters and theft
This course covers all aspects of modern web development
We covered twenty miles before stopping for lunch break
The patrol covered the entire northern border region yesterday
She covers technology news for the national newspaper daily
Three reporters covered the presidential campaign last year

definitions: frighten someone with threats or a show of force into doing something
examples: The bully tried to cow younger students into silence
They were cowed by the aggressive lawyer's intimidation tactics

definitions: move sideways or in an awkward way like a crab
complain in a bad-tempered way about something continuously
examples: The damaged plane crabbed sideways during the emergency landing
He crabbed along the narrow ledge holding the wall
She constantly crabs about the weather ruining her plans
Stop crabbing about every little thing that goes wrong

definitions: break or cause to break without complete separation of parts
find the solution to a difficult problem or code through effort
make or cause to make a sudden sharp or explosive sound
examples: The ice began to crack under their weight suddenly
She accidentally cracked the mirror while cleaning it
Detectives finally cracked the case after months of investigation
Hackers attempted to crack the bank's security system overnight
The whip cracked loudly in the circus performance tonight
Thunder cracked across the sky during the storm

definitions: make a rapid succession of slight cracking noises like burning wood
examples: The fire crackled cheerfully in the stone fireplace tonight
Bacon crackled in the pan filling the kitchen with aroma

definitions: hold gently and protectively in one's arms or hands with care
examples: She cradled the newborn baby in her loving arms
He cradled his injured hand against his chest carefully

definitions: make or construct something with skill and careful attention to detail
examples: The jeweler crafted a beautiful ring from platinum and diamonds
She carefully crafted her response to avoid any misunderstanding

definitions: force too many things or people into a space that is too small
study intensively over a short period of time just before an examination
examples: They crammed all their belongings into two small suitcases
Don't cram too many activities into your vacation schedule
Students often cram the night before important final exams
She crammed for the bar exam for three weeks

definitions: restrict or inhibit the development or free movement of something
experience or cause a painful involuntary contraction of a muscle
examples: These regulations cramp innovation in the technology startup sector
Don't let fear cramp your natural creative style
Her leg cramped during the marathon at mile twenty
Swimming in cold water can cramp your muscles quickly

definitions: stretch out one's neck to see something better or more clearly
examples: She craned her neck to see over the crowd
Everyone craned forward to hear the speaker's announcement better

definitions: turn a handle or lever to operate a machine or mechanism
start an engine or motor by turning a handle or key
examples: She cranked the old music box to hear the melody
He cranked the window open to let fresh air inside
They had to crank the vintage car to start it
Can you crank up the generator for emergency power?

definitions: defecate or expel feces from the body in vulgar or informal terms
examples: The dog crapped on the neighbor's lawn again yesterday
He needed to crap but couldn't find a bathroom

definitions: collide violently with an obstacle or another vehicle causing damage
fail suddenly and completely, especially of computer systems or markets
go to sleep or stay somewhere temporarily because of exhaustion
examples: The car crashed into a tree during the storm
Two planes nearly crashed on the foggy runway yesterday
The computer system crashed losing all unsaved data immediately
The stock market crashed causing widespread financial panic globally
I'm so tired I just want to crash immediately
Can I crash at your place tonight after party?

definitions: pack or store something in a wooden crate for transportation or storage
examples: Workers crated the fragile sculptures for international shipping today
They crated all the equipment before the warehouse move

definitions: feel a powerful desire for something, especially food or affection intensely
examples: Pregnant women often crave unusual food combinations during pregnancy
After years abroad, he craved his mother's cooking
